an3.137:4.1: “Mendicants, a hair blanket is said to be the worst kind of woven cloth.
an3.137:4.2: It’s cold in the cold, hot in the heat, ugly, smelly, and unpleasant to touch.
an3.137:4.3: In the same way, the teaching of Makkhali is said to be the worst of all the doctrines of the various ascetics and brahmins.
an3.137:5.1: Makkhali, that foolish man, has this doctrine and view:
an3.137:5.2: ‘There is no power in deeds, action, or energy.’
an3.137:5.3: Now, all the perfect ones, the fully awakened Buddhas who lived in the past taught the efficacy of deeds, action, and energy.
an3.137:5.4: But Makkhali opposes them by saying:
an3.137:5.5: ‘There is no power in deeds, action, or energy.’
an3.137:5.6: All the perfect ones, the fully awakened Buddhas who will live in the future will teach the efficacy of deeds, action, and energy.
an3.137:5.7: But Makkhali opposes them by saying:
an3.137:5.8: ‘There is no power in deeds, action, or energy.’
an3.137:5.9: I too, the perfect one, the fully awakened Buddha in the present, teach the efficacy of deeds, action, and energy.
an3.137:5.10: But Makkhali opposes me by saying:
an3.137:5.11: ‘There is no power in deeds, action, or energy.’
an3.137:6.1: It’s like a trap set at the mouth of a river, which would bring harm, suffering, calamity, and disaster for many fish.
an3.137:6.2: In the same way that foolish man Makkhali is a trap for humans, it seems to me. He has come into the world for the harm, suffering, calamity, and disaster of many beings.”
